docs.lead_paragraph: The Senate voted overwhelmingly today to cut Federal taxes substantially for the first time since 1981, as many Democrats supported the bill and President Clinton expressed optimism about reaching a bipartisan compromise on the final legislation. The legislation is similar in its broad outlines to a version passed by the House on Thursday on a largely party-line vote after a bitter debate. But the Senate bill contained enough compromises and specific provisions to woo Democrats and passed by 80 to 18, with 29 Democrats joining 51 Republicans voting in favor of it. Among those supporting the bill was the Democratic leader, Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota.

headline.main: Senate Passes Major Tax Cut By Big Margin

docs.abstract: Senate votes overwhelmingly to cut Federal taxes substantially for first time since 1981, as many Democrats support bill and Pres Clinton expresses optimism about reaching bipartisan compromise on final legislation; Clinton, although he has managed to set some limits on scope of cuts, has long since given into fundamental Republican demand for reductions in taxes for investors and middle-class families; Senate, like House, votes to give many families a $500-per-child tax credit and to reduce inheritance and estate taxes, all centerpieces of Republican agenda (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Recent settlements of huge class-action lawsuits involving smokers, industrial workers and consumers could be jeopardized by a Supreme Court ruling this week that tossed out a $1.3 billion deal in an asbestos case, lawyers said yesterday. The decision could also derail a new legal strategy in which some companies have tried to use the settlements to insulate themselves from future damages, including claims by people who have not yet been harmed by their work hazards or products.
docs.abstract: Legal experts say Supreme Court decision tossing out $1.3 billion settlement in asbestos case could jeopardize recent settlements of huge class-action lawsuits involving smokers, industrial workers and consumers and derail new legal strategy in which some companies have tried to use settlements to insulate themselves from future damages, including claims by people who have not yet been harmed by work hazards or products; say ruling, barring use of global settlements to resolve product liability claims, could upset asbestos industry's $1.5 billion settlement, and set back Liggett Group's efforts to settle huge anti-tobacco lawsuit outside framework of much broader deal being considered in Washington; ruling might offer grounds to overturn settlement involving sales practices by Prudential Insurance Co of America (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The MMI Companies agreed yesterday to acquire UnionAmerica Holdings P.L.C., an insurer in London, in a stock swap worth $187.2 million. MMI, a health care risk management and insurance company based in Deerfield, Ill., will exchange 0.836 share of its stock for each of UnionAmerica's 8.8 million shares outstanding. MMI shares fell $1.0625, to $25.4375, on the New York Stock Exchange. UnionAmerica's American depository receipts rose 87.5 cents, to $20.375.

docs.lead_paragraph: The House and Senate today approved sweeping legislation intended to balance the Federal budget for the first time since 1969. The two versions of the bill departed from each other in many significant details, however, and negotiators from the two chambers will now try to work out their differences and forge a compromise acceptable to President Clinton.

headline.main: House and Senate Pass Legislation to Balance Budget

docs.abstract: House and Senate approve sweeping legislation intended to balance Federal budget for first time since 1969, by votes of 270-162 and 73-27 respectively; both bills would balance budget by 2002, curb growth of Medicare and Medicaid, spend $16 billion on health care for uninsured children and restore cash assistance for legal immigrants losing benefits under 1996 welfare law; diverge in many significant details; negotiators will attempt to forge compromise acceptable to Pres Clinton; some provisions of both bills discussed; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Carol Reynolds, a dancer, actress and teacher in a Manhattan acting studio, had to give up her health insurance six years ago, when Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield eliminated group rates for associations that almost anyone could join. ''They made it so expensive for individuals that I couldn't handle it,'' said Ms. Reynolds, who will be 56 next month.

headline.main: In the Arts, Benefits Are Often 'Catch as Catch Can'

docs.lead_paragraph: Following is the 62-to-38 roll-call by which the Senate voted today to support gradual increases in the eligibility age for Medicare, to 67 from 65. A ''yes'' vote was a vote to increase the eligibility age. Voting ''yes'' were 50 Republicans and 12 Democrats. Voting ''no'' were 33 Democrats and 5 Republicans.

headline.main: How They Voted On Medicare Age

docs.lead_paragraph: For six months, as Congress has considered far-reaching proposals to regulate managed health care, the industry has waged a public relations offensive under the slogan ''putting patients first.'' But last week, lobbyists for the industry mobilized an extremely different offensive, resisting any requirement to pay for patients who go to hospital emergency rooms reporting severe pain.

headline.main: H.M.O.'s Fight Plan to Pay For Some Emergency Care

docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. James S. Todd, a New Jersey surgeon who was the executive vice president and chief executive officer of the American Medical Association from 1990 until he retired last year, died yesterday in Valley Hospital in Ridgewood, N.J. He was 65 and lived in Ridgewood. The cause was metastatic cancer, said James Stacey, a spokesman for the association, which has about 300,000 members.

headline.main: James S. Todd, 65, Surgeon Who Led Medical Association

docs.lead_paragraph: Following are excerpts from the proposal for a settlement reached last Friday by tobacco industry representatives, a group of state attorneys general and plaintiffs' lawyers. The agreement is expected to alter the nation's legal, regulatory and public health landscape permanently. Among other changes, the proposed settlement would require cigarette companies to pay $368.5 billion over the next 25 years to compensate states for the costs of treating smoking-related illness, to finance nationwide anti- smoking programs and to underwrite health care for millions of uninsured children. The text was downloaded from the Web site at http://stic.neu.edu run by the State Tobacco Information Center, an information clearing house created to provide information for the public and attorneys general involved in the case. Preamble This legislation would mandate a total reformation and restructuring of how tobacco products are manufactured, marketed and distributed in this country. The nation can thereby see real and swift progress in preventing underage use of tobacco, addressing the adverse health effects of tobacco use and changing the corporate culture of the tobacco industry.

headline.main: Excerpts From Agreement Between States and Tobacco Industry
